message.content:
cs.DC, cs.DB, cs.SE, cs.AR, cs.CE 

This paper is likely to belong to the Distributed, Parallel, and Cluster Computing (cs.DC) sub-category as it presents a scalable big data benchmarking methodology that implements the eight dwarfs on different software stacks. It could also belong to the Databases (cs.DB) sub-category as it identifies eight big data dwarfs that capture the common requirements of each class of unit of computation. Additionally, it could be classified under Software Engineering (cs.SE) as it constructs and tunes big data proxy benchmarks using the directed acyclic graph (DAG)-like combinations of the dwarf components. It may also fall under Architecture (cs.AR) as it discusses the micro-architecture, memory, and I/O characteristics of the proxy benchmarks. Finally, it could be categorized under Computer Engineering (cs.CE) as it presents a methodology for simulating big data workloads on different processors.
